Award.AwardTitle: SI2-SSI: CyberGIS Software Integration for Sustained Geospatial Innovation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Originally developed by geographers in the mid-1960s, Geographic Information Systems (GIS) have flourished since that time. In the foreseeable future, GIS software will continue to play essential roles for breaking through scientific challenges in numerous fields and improving decision-making practices with broad societal impacts. However, fulfilling such roles is increasingly dependent on the ability to handle very large spatiotemporal data sets and complex analysis software based on synthesizing computational and spatial thinking enabled by cyberinfrastructure, which conventional GIS-based software approaches do not provide. This project will establish CyberGIS as a fundamentally new software framework comprising a seamless integration of cyberinfrastructure, GIS, and spatial analysis/modeling capabilities. Specifically, the project will: 1) engage a multidisciplinary community through a participatory approach in evolving CyberGIS software requirements; 2) integrate and sustain a core set of composable, interoperable, manageable, and reusable CyberGIS software elements based on community-driven and open source strategies; 3) empower high-performance and scalable CyberGIS by exploiting spatial characteristics of data and analytical operations for achieving unprecedented capabilities for geospatial knowledge discovery; 4) enhance an online geospatial problem solving environment to allow for the contribution, sharing, and learning of CyberGIS software by numerous users, which fosters the development of education, outreach, and training programs crosscutting multiple disciplines; 5) deploy and test CyberGIS software by linking with national and international cyberinfrastructure to achieve scalability to significant sizes of geospatial problems, cyberinfrastructure resources, and user communities; and 6) evaluate and improve the CyberGIS framework through domain science applications and vibrant partnerships to gain better understanding of the complexity of coupled human-natural systems.

The CyberGIS software framework will shift the current paradigm of GIS and associated spatial analysis/modeling software to create scalable and sustainable software ecosystems while achieving groundbreaking scientific advances in understanding coupled human-natural systems that would be impossible otherwise. These advances will, for example, dramatically advance the understanding of disaster preparedness and response and impacts of global climate change. This framework will empower high-performance and collaborative geospatial problem solving and serve as a key driver for the interoperability of international cyberinfrastructure based on broad engagement of user communities related to GIS for both research and education purposes. The project will establish an industrial partnership with the Environmental Systems Research Institute (ESRI), collaborations with the Department of Energy's Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL) and the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) National Map Project, and international partnerships with several institutions in Australia, China, and the United Kingdom to effectively extend the benefits to the nation and society in significant ways.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The central goal of the NSF project: SI2-SSI: CyberGIS Software Integration for Sustained Geospatial Innovation (Award #1047916), was to establish cyberGIS as a fundamentally new software framework comprising a seamless integration of advanced cyberinfrastructure, geographic information science and systems, and spatial analysis and modeling capabilities for enabling widespread scientific advances and broad societal impacts.  

The intellectual merit of the project has not only successfully achieved the goal, but also established the new interdisclinary field of cyberGIS with a particular focus on advancing computational and data-intensive geospatial problem-solving within various research and education domains. Specifically, the novel cyberGIS software framework eliminates the limitations of monolithic and desktop-based GIS software, and represents a paradigm shift for GIS and associated spatial analysis and modeling software to become scalable software ecosystems based on advanced cyberinfrastructure. The cyberGIS software has achieved groundbreaking scientific advances that would be impossible or difficult otherwise. These advances, for example, have drastically improved the understanding of continental-scale flood inundation mapping. Broad and significant research progress has been made in the following five interdisciplinary and transdisciplinary fields: 1) advanced cyberinfrastructure and geographic information science; 2) bioenergy; 3) emergency management; 4) geography and spatial sciences; and 5) geosciences. 

The work done under this award has made significant broader impacts. The powerful cyberGIS software resulted from the project has been made available to general public, and a broad range of science and engineering communities while enhancing a number of undergraduate and graduate courses to empower interdisciplinary and transdisciplinaryeducation. The project has benefited a broad set of disciplines by creating new or enhancing existing geospatial software capabilities for tackling significant computational and data challenges. Examples of engagement of other disciplines include (a) hydrology, through active collaboration with the NSF HydroShare project; (b) Earth and environment science communities, through the development of CyberGIS Science Gateway with active inputs from user communities including the U.S. Geological Survey; (c) emergency management communities through our groundbreaking research on flood mapping, and (d) multiple social science research communities, through our data-intensive social media research. The nature of our project in terms of crosscutting advanced cyberinfrastructure and many domain science communities has demonstrated tremendous benefits of advanced cyberinfrastructure-based and integration-oriented cyberGIS software ecosystems to various research and education communities. 

The project has placed a major emphasis on education and workforce development, which is important to the future development of both advanced cyberinfrastructure and data-intensive geospatial sciences and technologies. The project was instrumental in the inaugural UCGIS summer school in 2017 that brought more than 30 students together from across the country to learn cutting-edge cyberGIS and geospatial data science. A large number of hands-on workshops and training courses were offered on multiple campuses and at various conferences and meetings with diverse and underrepresented participants engaged. Multiple course modules were developed to teach both graduate and undergraduate students the cyberGIS capabilities that have been advanced by the project. The project members including those from the project partners played active roles in creating reliable software while getting trained to work on a diverse set of advanced cyberinfrastructure capabilities and cyberGIS software. These members benefit from accessing a variety of software engineering practices and cutting-edge technologies, and have become a core workforce for sustaining cyberGIS software ecosystems. Overall, the project has addressed significant needs to bridge the digital divide between advanced cyberinfrastructure and various geospatial communities through academic, governmental, industrial, and international partnerships.
